elements.title: The Anchor Match Moment: When the First Number Meets the Host's Minimum
elements.problem: Tammy's emotional state during pricing is protective and frustrated. Her $5,000/month anchor is not a negotiating position ‚Äî it is her livelihood floor. When the first number she sees ($2,500/month single-tenant equivalent) falls below this anchor, the emotional response is not disappointment but threat. The affect heuristic converts this financial shortfall into a global negative judgment: the platform is not just inadequate on pricing but inadequate as a whole. 'The math doesn't add up' at 02:09 is not an analytical statement ‚Äî it is an emotional rejection wrapped in numerical language. No amount of subsequent explanation can fully repair the damage of a first number that triggers financial threat.
elements.solution: Design the pricing moment so that the first number the host encounters meets or exceeds her stated minimum. If the paired-tenant total for her unit genuinely reaches $5,000/month, show that number first. If it does not, show it relative to her vacancy alternative ($0/month during January-April) rather than relative to her peak-season anchor ($5,000/month). The emotional principle: never let the first number trigger threat. If the number is lower than the anchor, reframe the comparison before displaying the number. 'During your vacant months, Split Lease projects $3,200/month' is emotionally different from '$3,200/month from Split Lease' because the comparison anchor has been shifted from $5,000 (threat) to $0 (relief).

evidence.quote: The math doesn't add up.
evidence.insight: This is the affect heuristic in action: the negative feeling about the number transfers to a negative feeling about the entire platform. The emotion ('this doesn't work') precedes and overrides the analysis.

evidence.quote: I can look to people all day long at 5,000 a month for the two bedroom, one bath.
evidence.insight: The $5,000 anchor is stated with confidence and pride. It is not just a number ‚Äî it is evidence of her professional competence. Showing a number below it threatens her professional identity.

evidence.quote: The affect heuristic simplifies our lives by creating a world that is much tidier than reality. Good technologies have few costs in the imaginary world we inhabit, bad technologies have no benefits, and all decisions are easy.
evidence.insight: If the first number triggers negative affect, the host classifies the entire platform as 'bad technology' ‚Äî all costs, no benefits. The anchor match moment prevents this classification.

evidence.quote: The professionals were almost as susceptible to anchoring effects as business school students with no real-estate experience.
evidence.insight: Tammy's expertise does not protect her from anchoring. Even professional real estate hosts anchor on the first number they see.

elements.emotion_rationale: The pricing moment must resolve the threat of income loss before it can build excitement about income gain. Relief ('this meets my minimum') must precede excitement ('this could exceed my expectations').

do: Lead with the monthly total, not the nightly rate
Compare to the host's stated minimum: 'Your target: $5,000/month. Projected paired-tenant income: $4,800/month'
During vacancy season framing, compare to $0: 'January income without Split Lease: $0. With Split Lease: $3,200'
Use 'projected' or 'estimated' ‚Äî honest about uncertainty
dont: Promise exact income figures without qualification
Show nightly rates as the primary figure
Use aspirational language ('earn up to') that feels like a sales pitch
Minimize the gap between projected and target without explanation
copy_guidelines.example_good: Your 2BR target: $5,000/month. With 2 paired tenants at current Harlem rates: $4,800/month projected.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Earn up to $5,000+ per month with Split Lease! Start hosting today.

animation_feel.feel_description: The monthly total number should appear with a brief counting-up animation from $0 to the projected amount, arriving at the final number with a decisive settle. The motion should feel like a calculator completing a computation ‚Äî precise, not theatrical.

tension_relief.tension_point: Host sees the pricing screen and anticipates a number below her minimum ‚Äî System 1 is primed for threat
tension_relief.relief_point: The monthly total appears and either meets her minimum or is clearly framed against the vacancy alternative, resolving the financial threat
tension_relief.timing: Under 2 seconds from pricing screen load to the visible monthly total. The tension window must be as short as possible.

personalization_signals: Show the host's stated monthly minimum alongside the projection ‚Äî 'we know your target'
Reference her specific property: 'Your Harlem 2BR' not 'your listing'
Show seasonal context: 'January-April projected income' acknowledges her specific vacancy pattern

anti_patterns.pattern: Showing the per-night rate as the headline number
anti_patterns.reason: $85/night triggers 'small amount' associations and falls far below the host's $5,000/month anchor, creating immediate negative affect
anti_patterns.example_bad: $85/night ‚Äî Competitive rates for your Harlem apartment

anti_patterns.pattern: Using aspirational maximums instead of realistic projections
anti_patterns.reason: Tammy is a professional who values accuracy. 'Earn up to' language triggers her affect heuristic for 'sales pitch' (bad technology) rather than 'professional tool' (good technology)
anti_patterns.example_bad: Top Harlem hosts earn up to $6,000/month!

anti_patterns.pattern: Hiding the gap between projection and target
anti_patterns.reason: If the projection is $3,800 and her target is $5,000, hiding the gap feels dishonest. The gap must be acknowledged and contextualized (seasonal, ramp-up period, vacancy alternative)
anti_patterns.example_bad: Projected income: $3,800/month [no mention of the $1,200 gap]

elements.title: The Platform Trust Inversion: From Airbnb Betrayal to Host Sovereignty
elements.problem: Tammy's emotional relationship with booking platforms has been shaped by betrayal. Airbnb cancelled bookings during the pandemic, overrode damage policies, and sided with guests on refund disputes. This is not frustration ‚Äî it is betrayal: a trusted partner violated the implicit agreement. The resulting emotional state is not neutral skepticism but active hostility. Every platform interaction begins from a deficit of trust, not a position of neutrality. The affect heuristic has classified 'booking platforms' as 'bad technology' (all costs, no benefits), and this classification must be inverted before any feature evaluation can proceed.
elements.solution: Create an emotional inversion at first contact by making the host feel sovereign, not served. Sovereignty is the emotional opposite of Airbnb's betrayal: instead of the platform controlling the host, the host controls the platform. This is not about messaging ‚Äî it is about the felt experience of the first interaction. The host must feel, not just read, that she is in charge. Concrete implementation: (1) The first interactive element is a policy control, not a listing form. (2) Every automated message includes 'as per your rules' to reinforce sovereignty. (3) The platform never overrides a host decision without explicit consent. (4) When conflicts arise (guest dispute, cancellation request), the first communication to the host is: 'Here is what happened. What would you like to do?' not 'We have resolved this on your behalf.'

evidence.quote: I really can't stand Airbnb... that is the model of bad customer service... They take too much control over damages.
evidence.insight: The emotional core is 'too much control.' The antidote is not 'moderate control' but 'you have all the control.' The emotional inversion must be complete, not partial.

evidence.quote: VRBO... they kind of let you set the policy. They just kind of take a more hands off approach.
evidence.insight: VRBO is the emotional benchmark for 'acceptable platform.' Split Lease must feel more sovereign than VRBO, not just equivalent.

evidence.quote: People who had received a message extolling the benefits of a technology also changed their beliefs about its risks.
evidence.insight: One positive control experience (setting policies, having them respected) triggers the affect heuristic in reverse: the platform shifts from 'bad technology' to 'good technology,' and perceived risks decrease automatically.

evidence.quote: An availability cascade is a self-sustaining chain of events.
evidence.insight: The Airbnb betrayal cascade is self-reinforcing. Breaking it requires not just differentiation but emotional reversal: the host must feel more powerful on Split Lease than she feels off-platform.

elements.emotion_rationale: Before excitement about income or confidence about the model, the host must feel safe. Safety means: this platform will not betray me. My policies will not be overridden. My income will not be taken. Safety is the prerequisite for all other positive emotions in the host journey.

do: Use 'you' as the subject of every policy statement: 'You set. You decide. You control.'
Reference specific Airbnb pain points without naming Airbnb: 'Your cancellation policy is yours. We do not override it.'
Frame every platform action as 'on your behalf' or 'as per your rules'
Use declarative statements, not conditional: 'Your rules apply' not 'We try to respect your preferences'
dont: Use corporate hedging: 'We strive to respect host preferences' ‚Äî this signals that policy overrides are possible
Mention Airbnb by name ‚Äî naming the competitor activates the negative associative network
Promise and then add exceptions: 'Your policies apply (except in cases of...) ' ‚Äî any exception destroys sovereignty
Use passive voice about host policies: 'Policies are applied' should be 'You applied your policies'
copy_guidelines.example_good: Your rules. Your property. We enforce your terms ‚Äî not ours.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: We believe in supporting our host community with balanced policies that work for everyone.

animation_feel.feel_description: Policy confirmations should feel like a stamp being applied ‚Äî firm, definitive, irreversible. Not bouncy or playful. The motion communicates: this is decided, this is locked, this is yours.

tension_relief.tension_point: Host arrives on the platform with active hostility from Airbnb experiences, expecting to encounter the same pattern of platform overreach
tension_relief.relief_point: First interaction is setting her own policies, with the platform confirming: 'Your rules are now active.' The relief is: this platform defers to me
tension_relief.timing: Relief must come within the first 30 seconds of first platform visit. If the host spends more than 30 seconds without a sovereignty signal, the Airbnb cascade has already activated.

personalization_signals: Address her by name in policy confirmations: 'Tammy, your cancellation policy is now active'
Reference her portfolio size: 'Your 9 NYC units will all follow your rules unless you set unit-level overrides'
Show policy status on every page: a small persistent badge showing 'Your policies: Active' as constant sovereignty reassurance

anti_patterns.pattern: Generic trust badges without host-specific meaning
anti_patterns.reason: 'Trusted Platform' badges are abstract and trigger the availability of 'Airbnb also claimed to be trusted.' Specific policy statements are concrete and harder to disbelieve.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Split Lease ‚Äî The Trusted Platform for Professional Hosts

anti_patterns.pattern: Asking the host to accept platform terms before setting their own
anti_patterns.reason: A terms-of-service screen before policy configuration signals 'our rules first, your rules second' ‚Äî the exact Airbnb pattern. Sovereignty requires the host's rules to come first.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Before we get started, please review and accept our Terms of Service and Host Agreement.

anti_patterns.pattern: Automated actions taken without host awareness
anti_patterns.reason: Any automated action (cancellation, refund, pricing adjustment) performed without the host's knowledge recreates the Airbnb betrayal. Every automated action must be visible and reversible.
anti_patterns.example_bad: [System notification] We adjusted your pricing based on market conditions.

elements.title: Professional Recognition: The Platform Treats Her as a Portfolio Manager, Not a Hobby Host
elements.problem: Tammy manages 13-14 units with professional infrastructure: onsite managers, electronic locks, advance payment systems, guest vetting checklists. She is not a casual host renting a spare room ‚Äî she is a real estate professional. When the platform treats her like a first-time host (single-property wizards, basic explanations of hosting, tips for beginners), it misrecognizes her identity. This misrecognition triggers a specific emotional response: condescension. Being treated as less competent than she is triggers the affect heuristic negatively: 'This platform does not understand who I am' ‚Üí 'This platform is not for people like me' ‚Üí platform classified as 'bad technology.'
elements.solution: Signal professional recognition from the first interaction. The platform should detect portfolio-scale hosts (3+ units) and adapt the experience to match their expertise level. Concrete signals: (1) Use portfolio vocabulary: 'your portfolio,' 'your units,' 'your management team' ‚Äî not 'your space,' 'your place,' 'you as a host.' (2) Skip beginner explanations. If Tammy knows how electronic locks work, do not explain them. (3) Present advanced features first: batch listing, portfolio pricing, multi-unit analytics. (4) Acknowledge her infrastructure: 'You mentioned onsite managers ‚Äî we will route maintenance requests to them directly.' (5) The emotional principle: recognition of expertise is the strongest form of respect. The platform must recognize before it advises.

evidence.quote: I have like 13, 14 [units], so these are not [single-property situations].
evidence.insight: She corrects the conversational frame immediately: 'These are not' single-property situations. She needs the platform to understand her scale from the first interaction.

evidence.quote: We have onsite managers at all locations. If they have a problem, they come the next day or that day.
evidence.insight: She has professional infrastructure. The platform should integrate with her existing systems, not replace them with platform alternatives.

evidence.quote: The truth is that small schools are not better on average; they are simply more variable.
evidence.insight: The platform was designed from a sample that likely under-represents professional hosts. Recognizing professional-scale hosts requires design outside the normal distribution of user types.

evidence.quote: Good technologies have few costs in the imaginary world we inhabit.
evidence.insight: Professional recognition creates positive affect ('they understand me') that transfers to platform perception ('this is good technology'). Misrecognition creates negative affect that transfers identically.

elements.emotion_rationale: A professional host needs to feel confident that the platform is built for her scale and expertise. Confidence is the emotion that bridges trust (safety) and action (listing, pricing, booking). Without confidence in the platform's professional capability, the host will not commit her portfolio.

do: Use portfolio language: 'Manage your portfolio' not 'Manage your listing'
Reference her scale: 'With 9 NYC units, you can activate in batches'
Skip explanations she does not need: 'Set your advance payment terms' not 'Advance payment means...'
Treat operational details as known: 'Your electronic lock integration' not 'Do you use electronic locks?'
dont: Use beginner language: 'Getting started with hosting' ‚Äî she started years ago
Explain basic concepts: 'A listing is a page where guests can see your property'
Use singular property references: 'your apartment' when she has 13
Show onboarding tips for concepts she already uses: 'Pro tip: Try electronic locks!' ‚Äî she already has them
copy_guidelines.example_good: Your Harlem portfolio: 9 units ready for batch activation. Set pricing across all units or customize individually.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Welcome to Split Lease! Let's get your first listing set up. Here's how hosting works...

animation_feel.feel_description: Interactions should feel like a professional dashboard, not a consumer app. Minimal decorative animation. State changes are crisp and immediate. The motion language says: 'This is a tool, not a toy.'
animation_feel.duration_range: 100-200ms for state transitions ‚Äî fast, decisive, professional

tension_relief.tension_point: Host encounters the platform for the first time and expects to be treated like a beginner, based on experience with Airbnb's one-size-fits-all onboarding
tension_relief.relief_point: First screen shows portfolio-level language, multi-unit features, and no beginner content. The relief is: 'They know who I am.'
tension_relief.timing: Within 5 seconds of first platform view. If the host sees a single-property wizard or beginner content in the first 5 seconds, the condescension reaction has already activated.

personalization_signals: Portfolio count visible on dashboard: 'Your 9 NYC units + Bay Area properties'
Management infrastructure acknowledged: 'Onsite manager notifications enabled for your properties'
Pricing displayed in her native format: monthly totals per unit, not per-night rates
Seasonal patterns referenced: 'Your historically vacant months: January-April'

anti_patterns.pattern: One-size-fits-all onboarding that treats all hosts identically
anti_patterns.reason: A professional managing 13 units has categorically different needs than someone listing a spare room. Treating them the same condescends to the professional and overwhelms the casual host.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Step 1 of 6: Tell us about your space. Is this your first time hosting?

anti_patterns.pattern: Gamification or achievement badges for basic tasks
anti_patterns.reason: A professional host does not need a badge for 'completing your first listing.' Gamification signals 'this platform thinks hosting is a game,' which is insulting to someone whose livelihood depends on it.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Achievement Unlocked: Your first listing is live! üéâ

anti_patterns.pattern: Tooltips explaining concepts the host already uses
anti_patterns.reason: Explaining 'what is a security deposit' to a host who collects $5,000 deposits is condescending. The platform should assume professional knowledge and provide help only on request.
anti_patterns.example_bad: ‚ÑπÔ∏è A security deposit protects you against property damage. Learn more ‚Üí

elements.title: The Vacancy-Season Win: Transforming Empty Months From Loss to Bonus
elements.problem: Tammy's vacancy season (January-April) carries an emotional weight of loss. Empty units are not neutral ‚Äî they represent income she should be earning but is not. This loss aversion is amplified by the availability heuristic: she can vividly recall the financial impact of vacant months. The platform must transform the emotional frame of vacancy season from 'loss that I cannot prevent' to 'bonus income that I now capture.' This reframing is not about the numbers (though they matter) but about the feeling: vacancy season must feel like an opportunity seized, not a loss partially mitigated.
elements.solution: Design the vacancy-season experience to feel like bonus income, not partial recovery. The emotional reframing requires three elements: (1) Before the season: Frame the opportunity as additive. 'Last January earned $0. This January could earn $3,200.' The comparison is to $0 (the actual alternative), not to $5,000 (the peak-season anchor). (2) During the season: Show income accumulating in real time. A running total that updates after each booking payment creates positive availability ‚Äî the host can recall specific moments when money arrived during a previously dead month. (3) After the season: Present a seasonal summary that shows total vacancy-season income as a lump sum: 'January-April 2026: $12,800 earned from previously vacant months.' The lump sum creates a vivid, available memory that primes positive affect for the next vacancy season.

evidence.quote: From after Christmas to March, April, we were pretty much empty.
evidence.insight: She states the vacancy matter-of-factly, but 'pretty much empty' carries implicit frustration. She has accepted the loss as inevitable. The platform must make it feel optional.

evidence.quote: The split release would work for any honor if it was very lucrative.
evidence.insight: 'Lucrative' is the emotional threshold. The vacancy-season win must feel lucrative ‚Äî not just 'some income' but 'significant income from a previously dead period.'

evidence.quote: The emotional tail wags the rational dog.
evidence.insight: If vacancy-season income feels like a win (positive affect), the host will perceive the platform as less risky and more beneficial ‚Äî even outside vacancy season. The affect heuristic generalizes from the emotional experience to the entire platform assessment.

evidence.quote: A dramatic event temporarily increases the availability of its category.
evidence.insight: The first vacancy-season payment is a dramatic event (income during a previously dead month). It increases the availability of 'Split Lease generates income' in the host's memory, which primes positive assessment of all future platform interactions.

elements.emotion_rationale: After safety (platform trust) and relief (pricing acceptance), vacancy-season income should generate excitement ‚Äî the positive surprise of earning from a previously unproductive period. Excitement is the emotion that drives retention and word-of-mouth referral.

copy_guidelines.voice: concrete, comparative, celebratory without being cheesy
do: Compare vacancy-season income to $0 (the actual alternative), not to peak-season income
Use concrete dollar amounts: 'January earned $3,200' not 'January was profitable'
Frame as bonus: 'Extra income from months that were previously vacant'
Show running totals that accumulate over the season
dont: Compare vacancy-season income to peak-season income ‚Äî this makes $3,200 feel inadequate next to $5,000
Use vague language: 'Your vacancy season is going well' ‚Äî quantify everything
Minimize the achievement: '$3,200 may not be your full rate, but...' ‚Äî this introduces the negative comparison
Overpromise for next season: 'Next year will be even better!' ‚Äî stick to facts
copy_guidelines.example_good: January 2026 earnings: $3,200. Last January: $0. Your vacant months are now earning months.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: You earned $3,200 this January, which is 64% of your $5,000/month target.

animation_feel.easing: ease-out with a slight overshoot ‚Äî celebratory but not bouncy
animation_feel.feel_description: Income updates during vacancy season should feel like deposits landing: a brief scale-up animation on the running total, settling to its new value. The motion communicates: 'money just arrived.'

tension_relief.tension_point: Vacancy season begins and the host anticipates empty units and zero income, as in every prior year
tension_relief.relief_point: First booking confirmation arrives with a specific dollar amount and a visual running total that starts accumulating
tension_relief.timing: The first booking confirmation should arrive as close to the start of vacancy season as possible. Ideally, a booking is confirmed before the season begins, making the first day of vacancy season feel productive rather than empty.

personalization_signals: Property-specific performance: 'Your Harlem 2BR earned $3,200 in January' ‚Äî not generic 'your listings'
Running vacancy-season total displayed prominently on dashboard during Jan-April
Seasonal summary email at the end of April: 'Your vacancy-season report: 4 months, $12,800 earned'

anti_patterns.pattern: Comparing vacancy-season income to peak-season income
anti_patterns.reason: This triggers the anchoring effect against the host: $3,200 vs. $5,000 feels like a 36% shortfall. The correct comparison is $3,200 vs. $0 ‚Äî a 100% improvement.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Your January income: $3,200/month (64% of your $5,000 target)

anti_patterns.pattern: Using generic seasonal language instead of the host's specific property data
anti_patterns.reason: Tammy manages specific brownstones in Harlem. Generic 'your properties are earning' language feels impersonal and fails to create the vivid, available memory of specific income from specific units.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Great news ‚Äî your listings are generating income this winter!

anti_patterns.pattern: Failing to send income confirmations in real time
anti_patterns.reason: Income that arrives silently in a bank account has low availability. Income that is announced with a platform notification creates a vivid memory event that primes positive affect.
anti_patterns.example_bad: [No notification] ‚Äî payment deposited quietly to host's account

elements.title: The Law of Small Numbers Guard: Protecting the First Experience from Defining the Platform
elements.problem: Kahneman's law of small numbers predicts that Tammy will judge Split Lease based on her first 1-2 experiences, treating this tiny sample as representative of the platform's entire value. If the first proposal is from a weak guest (local, unverified employer, uncertain payment), she will generalize: 'Split Lease sends bad guests.' If the first vacancy-season month earns below her anchor, she will generalize: 'Split Lease does not work.' This judgment is sticky ‚Äî subsequent positive experiences will be insufficiently weighted because the first experience anchored her assessment. The emotional challenge is that the platform gets effectively one chance to pass the 'small sample' judgment.
elements.solution: Design the first experience to be disproportionately excellent. This is not about manipulation ‚Äî it is about ensuring that the first data point accurately represents the platform's capability, rather than the random variability that small samples inevitably contain. Concrete implementation: (1) Curate the first proposal: ensure the first guest presented to a professional host matches her vetting criteria (employed professional, non-local, verifiable employer). If no perfect match exists, delay the first proposal rather than sending a weak one. (2) Curate the first vacancy-season booking: if the platform subsidizes matching to guarantee a strong first booking, the cost is trivial compared to losing a 13-unit professional host. (3) After the first experience, explicitly contextualize it: 'This is your first booking. Here is what a typical month looks like.' Set expectations that reduce the anchoring of the first sample. (4) The emotional principle: the first experience creates a memory that is disproportionately available and emotionally charged. Make it the best possible representation of the platform.

evidence.quote: If you want practice on one or try out one, put together something that's profitable for us both.
evidence.insight: She is explicitly requesting a curated first experience: 'put together something.' She expects the platform to manage her trial, not leave it to chance.

evidence.quote: Local people... check from their employer... What are they there for?
evidence.insight: If the first guest fails any of these criteria, the small-sample judgment activates: 'Split Lease does not vet guests properly.' One data point defines the category.

evidence.quote: Intuitions about random sampling appear to satisfy the law of small numbers, which asserts that the law of large numbers applies to small numbers as well.
evidence.insight: Tammy will treat her first experience as representative. If it is bad, she believes the platform is bad. The platform must ensure the first experience is genuinely representative of its best capability.

evidence.source: kahneman-part2-heuristics-biases.txt, A Bias of Confidence Over Doubt
evidence.quote: We are prone to exaggerate the consistency and coherence of what we see.
evidence.insight: After one good experience, Tammy will exaggerate the platform's consistency ('they always send good guests'). After one bad experience, she will exaggerate the opposite. The first data point determines which exaggeration takes hold.

elements.emotion_rationale: After the first successful experience, the host needs to feel forward momentum: 'This is working, and it will keep working.' Momentum is the emotion that bridges one-time trial to ongoing retention. Without momentum, each subsequent booking is evaluated independently rather than as part of a trend.

do: After the first booking: 'Your first booking is complete. Here is what to expect next month.'
Contextualize: 'Hosts with similar portfolios typically see 3-4 bookings per unit during vacancy season'
Build on the specific success: 'Your guest Sarah at Columbia Presbyterian gave your brownstone a 5-star internal rating'
Create forward expectation: 'February bookings are already being matched for your units'
dont: Celebrate the first booking as though it is surprising: 'Wow, your first booking!' ‚Äî this signals the platform is unsure of itself
Leave the first booking uncontextualized, letting the host wonder if it is typical or an outlier
Send generic congratulations without specific next steps
Allow long gaps between first and second experiences ‚Äî momentum requires continuity
copy_guidelines.example_good: First booking complete: Sarah K., nurse at Columbia Presbyterian, January 5-31. Next: 2 professionals are pending for February. Your Harlem 2BR is building its track record.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Congratulations on your first booking! üéä We hope to see more activity soon.

animation_feel.feel_description: Each successful experience should add to a visual accumulation ‚Äî a timeline that extends, a counter that increments, a progress bar that fills. The motion communicates: 'this is building, this is growing, this is a trend.'

tension_relief.tension_point: Host has committed to a vacancy-season trial and is waiting for the first result ‚Äî uncertainty is at maximum
tension_relief.relief_point: First booking is confirmed with a guest who matches all her vetting criteria, with specific income amount shown
tension_relief.timing: The first booking confirmation should arrive within the first week of the trial period. Longer delays allow the availability heuristic to fill the gap with worst-case scenarios.

personalization_signals: First guest matches the host's specific criteria (employed professional, non-local, verifiable employer)
Income from first booking is shown relative to the vacancy alternative: 'January week 1: $800. Without Split Lease: $0'
Pipeline visibility: 'February: 2 professionals are pending' ‚Äî the host can see that the trend will continue
Post-first-booking summary includes the guest's feedback about the property

anti_patterns.pattern: Sending the first proposal from a guest who does not match the host's criteria
anti_patterns.reason: One mismatched proposal defines the platform forever in the host's assessment. The law of small numbers guarantees that this single data point will represent 'the kind of guests Split Lease sends.'
anti_patterns.example_bad: New proposal from John D., self-employed, local resident, credit card on file. [No employer, local, no deposit verification ‚Äî fails every criterion]

anti_patterns.pattern: Letting the first vacancy-season month underperform without explanation
anti_patterns.reason: An unexplained underperformance in month one anchors the entire seasonal assessment negatively. Context ('January is typically the slowest; February picks up') must be provided proactively.
anti_patterns.example_bad: January income: $1,800 [silence ‚Äî no context, no February pipeline visibility]

anti_patterns.pattern: Treating the first experience identically to all subsequent experiences
anti_patterns.reason: The first experience is disproportionately influential. It deserves disproportionate attention: curated guest matching, proactive communication, income confirmation within hours not days, and personal follow-up.
anti_patterns.example_bad: [Automated system notification] Booking confirmed. Payment will be deposited in 3-5 business days.
